newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's Jospin clashes with Chirac in cabinet.
newsitem.headline: France's Jospin clashes with Chirac in cabinet.

text.p: French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, responding to criticism from Gaullist President Jacques Chirac, reminded the head of state of their respective duties at a cabinet meeting on Wednesday, a government spokeswoman said.
Chirac broke an uneasy peace with the new leftist government on Monday, critcising it on policies ranging from privatisation to nuclear power, Europe and immigration.

"Following the statements of the president on July 14, the prime minister recalled in cabinet the prerogatives which constitutionally are those of the president and the prime minister," spokeswoman Catherine Trautmann told reporters.

Chirac, in a traditional interview broadcast on Bastille national day, laid out a roadmap of potential conflicts with the cabinet, with the transition to the single European currency near the top of the list.

Chirac said the Constitution gave him "a pre-eminent role -- the last word" on matters ranging from the transition to a single currency and maintaining social cohesion to upholding France's high-technology industries.
Jospin's Socialist Party has accused Chirac, shorn of much of his power by the left-wing election victory, of going too far in his criticism.
